text: [Music]
we're going to demonstrate the proper
way to do a bench press versus the way
you see a lot of people do it in the gym
this is usually the most common
exercises you see for training chest
especially the pectoralis major but it
also involves your anterior deltoids and
your triceps to a great degree there's a
three point contact for the benchpress
the first point of contact is his head
and upper back so we want to make sure
that both of these are flat on the bench
the other thing that's going to happen
though is he's also going to make sure
that his hips his glutes are fully
pressed into the bench and that his feet
are flat on the floor from those three
points he's going to derive his power in
order to push well we want to make sure
is he's maintaining a slight arch in his
back as a matter of fact if I were to
reach under him right now I could
actually reach all the way across
underneath him as he reaches up to take
the bar the grip is slightly wider than
shoulder width now what he's going to do
is when he lowers the bar he's aiming
for the lower portion of his chest right
around nipple level and as he drives
back up you'll notice he's keeping his
shoulders back and he's pushing through
and the bar is actually making a slight
arc from his chest to back over towards
over his face not all the way back
necessarily he's going to hold his
breath slightly as he drives up and then
he can take a breath as he finishes his
arms straighten out at the top
he's driving primarily with the chest
but we want to make sure he does is he
doesn't flare his elbows out to the side
that puts a tremendous amount of strain
on the rotator cuff as well so what
we're gonna do is the elbows come
slightly forward he drives up keeping
his head upper back hips and feet
pressed down in order to derive power
nice finishing position and it's a slow
controlled movement what we want to make
sure you don't do is bounce the bar at
the end of the motion it's not a rebound
benchpress in this case it's nice tight
technique in order to finish but a
typical benchpress is going to be
shoulder blades tucked back finishing in
a strong position control bar movement
all the way through maintaining his
three points of contact
